column4: Need SSH help: where do I put my private key on my remote machine (I'm using cygwin on remote machine)?
why do you want your private key on the remote machine?
nope :/
you mean "client" by "remote"?

the private key is yours, you keep it on the client usually as ~/.ssh/id_rsa .  On the server you add your ~/.ssh/id_rsa.password.pub (corresponding to your private key on the client)  to ~/.ssh/authorized_keys on the server
though you can just use ssh-copy-id to do all the work for you
I have that on both my desktop (server) and laptop (client). Which do I execute ssh-copy-id on?
no wait, I don't have ssh-copy-id on my laptop
on your client (see 'man ssh-copy-id')
I don't have it on my client. I put the public key in ~/.ssh/authorized_keys on my server, so where should I put the private key on my cygwin client?
then you don't need to do anything else on the server (that's what ssh-copy-id does).  I have no idea how cygwin works
just make some file named id_rsa in .ssh?
it's not "some file".  It's your private key
but it's just text in a file
sure, containing your private key
so if I make a file 'id_rsa' and put the private key in there that's all I need? (~/.ssh/id_rsa)
yeah, ssh will use that key by default
ok, then is there a way to make sure that I've done everything correctly?
try it? :P
I put the private key in id_rsa and when I connect it tells me WARNING: UNPROTECTED PRIVATE KEY FILE! Permissions for .ssh/id_rsa are too open
chmod 600 ~/.ssh/id_rsa
thanks
